DOC.HEAD: US Seeking Extradition of Alleged Cocaine Smugglers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to CORRECT arrest of extradition suspects not linked to nation's largest drug seizure. Picks up 9th graf pvs, `Earlier in ...'
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. government announced Saturday it is seeking the extradition of a mayor and two other men on cocaine-trafficking charges. The embassy news release followed a federal police announcement of the nation's largest drug seizure in a separate case. Police said they confiscated more than 5,000 pounds of cocaine worth an estimated $3.8 billion. The extradition request named Zacapa Mayor Arnoldo Vargas Estrada, 52; Otto Evelio Quiro Davila, 34, and Victor Enrique Escobar Arias, 37. The U.S. Embassy said it informed the Foreign Ministry on Dec. 20 that the Justice Department wants to prosecute the men on charges of importing and distributing cocaine in the United States. ``The government of Guatemala acted rapidly to detain these individuals,'' the embassy said, referring to the arrests Thursday in Zacapa, about 90 miles east of the capital of Guatemala City. Officials said they seized more than 630 pounds of cocaine with a value of some $57.4 million dollars when the three men were arrested. The U.S. Drug Enforcement Agency was involved in the arrests, according to Guatemalan officials. The embassy expressed pleasure ``with this cooperation on the part of the Guatemalan government.'' Federal police Friday night said they seized 1,522 packages of cocaine, each weighing 3.3 pounds, in bags and car tires stashed in several parts of Guatemala City. Five men were arrested in that case. Earlier in the week, the army dismissed Col. CarlosRene Ochoa Ruiz, as well as Capts. Hugo Leonel Perez Franco and Jose Maria Flores Montes for alleged involvement in drug trafficking. It turned their cases over to civilian courts. There have been rumors the United States also was seeking extradition of the officers, but the embassy made no reference to such a request. Vargas, who won re-election in November as mayor for the National Center Union, denied the charges and told reporters the allegations were meant to damage the election chances of his party's standard-bearer, Jorge Carpio Nicolle. Carpio Nicolle faces Jorge Serrano Elias in a presidential runoff vote on Jan. 6. The embassy statement said the United States is ``confident that whoever wins the second round (of elections) will be totally dedicated to continuing the broad cooperation which our two governments have shown in this field.'' Drug trafficking has flourished in this Central American nation of 9 million people since President Vinicio Cerezo came into office in 1986 after decades of military rule.

DOC.HEAD: Man Surrenders After Holding S&L Employees Hostage
DOC.TEXT: A gunman took three people hostage Saturday when police foiled his attempt to flee a savings and loan after robbing it. He surrendered four hours later, authorities said. No shots were fired and no one was injured, police said. David Amburgey, 33, of Montrose, was arrested shortly after releasing Century Savings and Loan president Louis Schick, vice president Don Jones and an unidentified female employee, said Police Chief James Montoya. The gunman entered the savings and loan just before noon and robbed it of an undetermined amount of cash, which was later recovered, Montoya said. An employee tripped a silent alarm and two policemen confronted Amburgey as he tried to leave through a back door, Montoya said. Amburgey, armed with a .22-caliber semiautomatic pistol, went back inside and took the three hostages, Montoya said. He surrendered after a state trooper negotiating the hostages' release told him police knew who he was and had towed away his getaway car, Montoya said. Amburgey, who was held Saturday night at the Las Animas County Jail, told police he was out of work and needed money, Montoya said. Trinidad is a small mining town in southern Colorado.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Reject Five Election Results
DOC.TEXT: Election victories claimed by the governing party in five small Yucatan state towns were thrown out Saturday and new votes were ordered. The state Electoral College also declared the opposition National Action Party the victor in the town of Dzan during the Nov. 25 elections. Opposition parties have accused the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party of widespread fraud during recent elections in the states of Yucatan, Coahuila, Mexico and Hidalgo. The government has vowed to clean up the electoral process and officials have recognized opposition party victories in a few cities in each state, including the Yucatan state capital of Merida. The government Notimex news agency said the Electoral College voided the elections in Sucila, Tetiz, Santa Elena, Panaba and Tekit. It said new elections are to be held within 60 days. Officials had earlier declared the governing party the victor in all but a handful of the 106 municipalities that held elections Nov. 25. Also Saturday, arraignments were held for 25 people arrested Friday in Valladolid during a protest of alleged election fraud, Notimex reported. Among those arraigned was National Action Party mayoral candidate Justo Enrique Herrera Silva. Another 114 of those arrested were released for lack of evidence, according to local officials quoted by Notimex. Witnesses said police used to tear gas to disperse protesters, who seized city hall. Notimex said municipal police chief Alfonso Diaz Arzapalo claimed he was injured, robbed of $500 and stripped of his clothes during the clashes.

DOC.HEAD: Teen Charged In Movie Shootout
DOC.TEXT: A teen-ager was charged in the Christmas Day shootout at a screening of ``The Godfather Part III'' that left one person dead and three others wounded, police said Saturday. Lawrence Bartley, 17, of Laurelton on Long Island, was charged Thursday with reckless endangerment and criminal possession of a weapon, said officer Andrew DiSimone, a Nassau County police spokesman. The shooting followed a shouting match between two groups of teen-agers at Sunrise Cinema in Valley Stream on Long Island. About 700 panicked moviegoers fled when the shooting began about an hour into the gangster film. A 15-year-old boy was shot in the head and died the next day. Three other bystanders were wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Three US Sailors Killed in Hotel Fire
DOC.TEXT: At least three U.S. sailors died early Sunday in a fire that swept through a hotel filled with American servicemen en route to the Persian Gulf, police said. The fire at the Royal Lodge Hotel, about one mile from the U.S.-operated Subic Bay Naval Base, also killed a Filipino woman. Investigators said one of the victims was assigned to the aircraft carrier USS Ranger, which is part of a convoy that arrived in the Philippines on Thursday from San Diego on its way to the gulf. The other two victims were also believed assigned to the task force. The U.S. Navy withheld the names of those killed pending notification of relatives. Police said the cause of the fire was not immediately known.

DOC.HEAD: Disgraced Former President Ends Two-Year Exile to Return to Seoul
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 3-4 pvs, `The route ...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Chun arriving at home. Picks up 5th graf pvs, `Dissidents have ...'
DOC.TEXT: Disgraced former president Chun Doo-hwan ended two years of self-imposed exile in a remote mountain temple Sunday to return to Seoul and almost certain political controversy. Chun, who was accompanied by his wife and aides, left the 14th century Buddhist temple in the snow-capped eastern mountains with a police escort, news reports said. About 2,500 riot police blocked streets and alleyways near Chun's house in western Seoul to check identifications and prevent possible protests. Opponents attacked the house repeatedly before Chun's departure. It has remained under heavy guard during his exile. ``In the future, I will continue to live as an ordinary citizen,'' said the former general in a statement at the temple. Dissidents have asked the government to prosecute Chun, contending he ordered the military to crush a 1980 pro-democracy uprising in Kwangju. By official count, about 200 people were killed in the uprising. The former president left Seoul to go into rural exile in November 1988 after apologizing on national television for abuses of power during his seven- year rule which ended in 1987. Chun left office after accepting opposition demands for direct popular elections following mass anti-government protests in 1987. He hand-picked Roh Tae-woo as the governing party candidate, and Roh won the presidency by a narrow margin in December 1987. Roh, a former general who helped Chun seize power in 1980, has appealed to the nation for mercy for Chun. A dozen of Chun's relatives and associates have been convicted of corruption and imprisoned since Roh took office.

DOC.HEAD: Hijackers Arrested After Freeing Passengers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead to CLARIFY incident was hijacking
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PAR16
DOC.TEXT: Two army deserters who hijacked an airliner and held dozens of hostages during a two-day standoff surrendered Sunday after freeing all passengers and crew, the official Algerian news agency reported. The hijackers were taken into custody without violence after releasing the pilot and co-pilot of the state-owned Air Algerie Boeing 737, the news agency said. Earlier, 46 remaining passengers were freed. There were no reports of injuries. The hijackers' names were not immediately released by authorities, and the motive for the incident was unclear. The APS news agency reported the men were deserters from the Saharan town of Ghardaia, where the flight began late Friday. The hijackers, who were armed, had demanded 20 hours' worth of fuel to fly to another country. The jet, carrying 82 passengers and six crew members, was forced to land in the eastern city of Annaba early Saturday after officials in Carthage, Tunisia, turned the flight away. Egyptian officials refused Saturday to allow the hijackers to fly there. The hijackers seized the aircraft shortly after takeoff from Ghardaia, a popular winter resort. It was bound for the Algerian capital of Algiers. According to airline officials and accounts by freed passengers, the pair produced a pistol and submachine gun shortly after takeoff. One hijacker took control of the cabin and the other watched over the passengers, forcing the women to the front of the plane. ``The plane started rolling, but not like an air pocket,'' French passenger Paulette Thibule, 67, told the French television network La Cinq. ``The stewardesses got moving toward the front. That's when I understood there was a struggle in the cockpit.'' Talks with the hijackers resumed at dawn Sunday. Interior Minister Mohammad Saleh Mohammedi first negotiated the release of the remaining people on board. A short while later, he persuaded the two men to surrender, witnesses said. The hijackers gave up after freeing the pilot and co-pilot. Police had surrounded the plane, although other flights took off and landed at the airport, about 250 miles east of Algiers. On Saturday, the two hijackers released 36 passengers, mostly children, elderly people and foreigners. Air Algerie said there were 14 foreign nationals among the passengers. Kahlouche said the foreigners included French, German, Italian and Japanese citizens. The State Department said no Americans were on the flight. Late Saturday, there were conflicting reports about the hijackers. Transport Minister Hassan Kahlouche said the hijackers were Algerian, and made no political statements or demands. But an Algerian official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the hijackers probably were Islamic fundamentalists protesting a crackdown against an allied Moslem movement in Tunisia. Algeria is home to North Africa's most powerful Islamic fundamentalist movement, which took a majority of seats in local and municipal elections in June. Another Algerian official quoted freed passengers as saying the hijackers ``showed no physical or verbal violent intentions'' and made no statements about their motives. Algeria has long experience in negotiating the release of hostages, most recently in April 1988 when mediators won the freedom of 31 hostages aboard a hijacked Kuwait Airways jet. Western officials criticized Algeria for releasing the hijackers, who killed two people. Algerian diplomats played a key role in winning the 1981 release of Americans held hostage at the U.S. Embassy in Iran. They also brokered the release of many Western hostages in Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: 43 Killed As Boats Capsize
DOC.TEXT: At least 43 people, including 32 schoolchildren, drowned when two boats capsized in a river in eastern India, news reports said Sunday. Press Trust of India said 120 people were rescued after Saturday's accident in Jalmagi river in West Bengal state. The reports said the boats were bringing back students and teachers of several elementary schools from an annual sports competition at a nearby town, 745 miles southeast of New Delhi. Press Trust said the boats were tied together and were being steered by a teen-age oarsman. The boats collided and capsized when the boy lost control in the turbulent river, Press Trust of India said quoting the district police chief, D.K. Basu. The United News of India said the bodies of 32 children and 11 teachers were found by rescuers.

DOC.HEAD: Iran's First Test-Tube Babies Born
DOC.TEXT: Iran's first test-tube babies were born in the city of Yazd in central Iran, the Islamic Rebublic News Agency reported Sunday. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the first baby, a girl, was born to 36-year-old woman at the city's Afshar Yazd University hospital Saturday morning. An hour later, another woman gave birth to twins, a girl and a boy. Dr. Abbas Aflatounian, head of the Infertility Research Center at the hospital, said the births were by Caesarian section, and that all three babies and their mothers were in ``perfect condition,'' IRNA reported. Aflatounian said that during the center's year-long fertilization and insemination programs, 30 successful pregnancies had been registered. Dr. Mohammad Faqihi, the university's chancellor, said there were about one million infertile couples in Iran, and that 7,000 of them had applied for help at the center.

DOC.HEAD: New York Mayor Says 1990 Was A Year Of `Dreams Deferred'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RETRANSMITTING to fix cycle designator
DOC.HEAD: With NC Speaker, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Mayor David Dinkins, reflecting on his first year in office, says he's proud that he maintained the city's bond rating despite a budget deficit. But the city's first black mayor said he wishes he could have spent less time dealing with fiscal problems and more time on the social issues that propelled him into office. ``I look forward to the day when we will be able to move ahead on some of the dreams that have been, for the moment at least, deferred,'' Dinkins said during a recent interview. A projected gap of at least $250 million in the city's 1991 fiscal year budget has forced the mayor to cut funds in virtually every area, from education and street cleaning to libraries and bridge repair. According to a federal report released the week before Christmas, the New York metropolitan region lost an estimated 100,000 jobs in private industry in 1990, half of them in New York City. The fiscal crisis has made it difficult for Dinkins to devote time to the city's poor and young, whose plight he promised to improve during his campaign for mayor. Dinkins acknowledged that his inability to focus on social issues has made some of his strongest supporters impatient for results. A recent New York Newsday poll showed that only 33 percent of those interviewed approved of his job performance, down from 53 percent in June. The biggest decline in approval came among blacks - still largely supportive of him but down to 65 percent from 76 percent - and Manhattan residents. Dinkins said the high points of his first year included anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela's visit; a decision by the Democratic Party to hold its 1992 convention here; and his City Hall speech calling for racial harmony as New Yorkers awaited a verdict in the first trial in the slaying of a black teen-ager in a mob attack in a predominantly white neighborhood in Brooklyn. While the city's crime rate has soared, with annual city murders topping 2,000 for the first time, Dinkins said he is proud of his ``Safe Streets, Safe City'' plan to hire thousands of new police officers. But he failed to win the approval of the crime plan by the state Legislature, which recessed two weeks ago without acting on it. Asked about his priorities for 1992, the mayor said he would focus first on fiscal stability, followed by public safety and then education, youth services and health care. ``There are many more things I had hoped to accomplish, especially in the areas of human service, that just plain require money,'' Dinkins admitted. How long dreams continue to be deferred, he said, will depend on ``when we get some money.'' Dinkins also said he believed that in general, more was expected of him than of past mayors, ``not so much because I am an African American, per se, but because the coalition that elected me ... (was) very dissatisfied in the closing years of the stewardship of my predecessor (Edward Koch). ``And they saw this as an opportunity for things to be different in some particulars. And we don't have the ability to change these things overnight for a variety of reasons,'' Dinkins said. ``And especially now, as there's the need ... to cut back and downsize, it's going to be even more difficult and painful.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Say New Year's Eve Plot to Murder Officers Foiled
DOC.TEXT: A gang's plot to murder police officers on New Year's Eve has been foiled by the arrests of three young men and seizure of weapons, police said. The alleged plot apparently was in retaliation for police crackdowns on gang-controlled drug operations in the Van Nuys and Sylmar areas of the San Fernando Valley, said Lt. Jim Vojtecky. ``As early as September, we began getting inforamtion that local street gangs were getting ... a little irritated, and we had indications they were going to attempt to kill a cop because we were screwing up their drug operations in the streets,'' Vojtecky said. Gang violence in the nation's second-largest city reached record levels during 1990. As of Nov. 30, gang violence had accounted for 315 deaths in 1990, a 12.4 percent jump over 1989, when 303 people died in gang attacks. Vojtecky said tension between police and gangs in the Van Nuys area has been building for months. Recent information from informants convinced police that an attempt to kill police would be made on New Year's Eve, Vojtecky said. In early morning raids Saturday, police seized two rifles, one with a sawed-off barrel, one handgun and 163 rounds of ammunition. Sergio Camarena, Cesar Reveles and Hector Aleman, all 18, were taken into custody. Camarena and Reveles were booked for investigation of conspiracy to commit murder and Aleman was booked for possession of a sawed-off rifle. The three belonged to the same gang, which Vojtecky declined to identify in keeping with departmental policy designed to avoid giving publicity to individual gangs. Vojtecky said officers did not have time to determine how the alleged murder plot was to be carried out. Police believe the plot was foiled by the arrests. However, a bulletin was issued advising officers throughout Los Angeles to be careful on New Year's Eve. Saturday's arrests followed by hours a spate of gang violence in the region that left a 13-year-old boy dead and a girl critically wounded. The 13-year-old boy was shot while sleeping in the living room of his grandmother's home in suburban Pomona. Police said the gunman apparently mistook the youth, visiting from Claremont, for a member of a local gang. The girl was shot in the head when several rounds were fired through the living room window of her home in southwest Los Angeles. The 13-year-old was listed in very critical condition at Cedar-Sinai Medical Center. Police Lt. Joe Germain said investigators suspect it was gang gunfire but did not know if the girl was the intended victim.

DOC.HEAD: South Korea Bans Ads That Discriminate Against Women
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Ministry says classified ads that discriminate against women will be banned after Jan. 1 and employers who place them will be fined $3,500. In a ruling published Sunday, the ministry said that employment for jobs calling for ``single'' or ``good-looking'' applicants will be banned. Also illegal will be ads for jobs saying ``Only male college graduate wanted,'' ``Males welcome'' and ``Completion or exemption of military service preferred.'' Feminists consider the ruling long overdue, but say it is unlikely to force change in South Korea's male-dominated society.

DOC.HEAD: Siberians Riot over Wine, Vodka Shortage Before New Year's
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of people staged a ``wine riot'' in a Siberian city on Sunday, angry that they would have to celebrate New Year's without alcohol, Tass reported. The shortage of spirits for the New Year's holiday - the most festive day on the Soviet calendar - ``overfilled the cup of tolerance of city residents,'' the official news agency said. The rioters in Chita, 2,976 miles east of Moscow, blocked traffic and lit bonfires to protest the lack of wine, vodka and other goods, Tass said. President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his supporters have warned of social unrest because of worsening shortages of a variety of goods. Food, medicine and consumer goods are so scarce that Gorbachev has had to ask the West for help, which is arriving from private charities and governments worldwide. Tass said the ``wine riot'' began after people became fed up after long hours of waiting in line at stores. A crowd went onto one of the city's main highways, blocked traffic and lit bonfires made of boards, fences and boxes, it said. Protests demanded a meeting with local authorities to complain about empty shelves in stores selling food and manufactured goods, interruptions of the water and electricity supplies, corruption in trade and ``the multi-month `wine famine,''' Tass said. Firefighters and police managed to get the crowd to disperse, but Tass said the situation in Chita, a city of 315,000 people, ``remains uneasy.''

DOC.HEAD: Communist Party Adopts Cautious Blueprint for the '90s
DOC.TEXT: The Communist Party on Sunday adopted a cautious economic and social blueprint for the 1990s, stressing stability and self-reliance and rejecting the infatuation with rapid reform of the 1980s. ``We must guard against and overcome the tendency of being impatient for success, and strive to avoid a recurrence of big ups and downs in economic life,'' the ruling party's Central Committee said in a communique adopted at a closed-door, six-day meeting that ended Sunday. The evening television news showed party General Secretary Jiang Zemin in a dark gray Mao suit presiding over the opening session in the Great Hall of the People, with 171 full members and 107 alternates in attendance along with several hundred retired party elders. Neither Jiang's opening speech nor the comments of any individual members were released. The meeting was postponed for weeks as committee members argued over drafts of new Five- and Ten-Year Plans to take effect on New Years' Day and guide China's centrally planned economy into the 21st century. The official Xinhua News Agency's report of the session indicated the committee did not approve any existing drafts. Instead, Xinhua said the government will now ``map out'' the plans, presumably based on the Central Committee communique. The blueprint gives priority in state spending to agriculture, basic industries and infrastructure. It also calls for more attention to national defense, which received a shrinking share of the budget during the 1980s. Little space is given in the communique to new economic reforms that would continue China's decade-old program of supplementing central planning with market forces. Reform was one of the key issues dividing Central Committee members. Party elders such as 86-year-old Chen Yun, who played a key role in the early years of reform, accused younger liberals of forgetting that the reforms were intended to strengthen socialism, not build capitalism. Private enterprise and free markets should supplement the state sector but not replace it, he argued. The conservatives appeared to have won, judging from the brevity of the references to reform and the repeated calls for strengthening the inefficient, debt-ridden state-owned sector. However, a Western diplomat cautioned that it is too soon to make an assessment. The document may have been drafted with a conservative slant in order to win passage, while containing enough references to improving efficiency to allow for real change. The only sentence that specifically deals with new reforms says structural changes are needed in ``the fields of enterprises, circulation, prices, finance, taxation, banking, planning, investment and labor and wages'' - a broad list. No detailed suggestions are made. The communique says economic growth should be sustained and stable, based on the ``principle of doing what is within our capacity.'' No targets were set, but Premier Li Peng recently said average annual growth of 6 percent would be appropriate - down from an average of nearly 10 percent during most of the 1980s. During the 1980s, however, the economy experienced several swings from too rapid expansion and rising inflation to abrupt government-ordered slowdowns designed to curb the inflation. Such swings gave China a reputation for economic instability. The battle between Beijing and regional authorities for control over tax revenues appears unresolved. The document says ``overall regulation and control'' of the economy is needed, but concludes evenhandedly: ``It is necessary to handle properly the relations between the central and the local authorities ... And give full scope to the initiative of both.'' The 1990s will be pivotal years for China, says the document, which alludes only vaguely to the collapse of socialism in many other countries. ``Success or failure in our efforts ... to greatly promote economic growth and social progress will have a direct bearing on the rise or fall of China's socialist system.'' ``We should strengthen ideological and political work in real ernest, carry out in-depth education in patriotism, collectivism and socialism, and re-energize the national spirit.'' Such calls have become routine since the violent crushing of last year's massive democracy movement, which is not mentioned in the communique. A single sentence says efforts should be made to ``push forward political structural reform and expand socialist democracy,'' but there is no mention of any specific reforms. When reformist fever peaked in 1987, there were calls for separating the party and government functions, but such ideas have been anathema since the conservative backlash to the democracy movement.

DOC.HEAD: New Year Holds Promise for High Tech; Not for Autos and Housing.
DOC.TEXT: The new year holds promise for high-technology and medical companies despite the deepening economic slump, but many businesses tied to automobiles and housing face dim prospects, a government forecast said Sunday. The Commerce Department, in its 32nd annual forecast of winners and losers in American business, predicted that 110 of 184 manufacturing industries it surveyed would enjoy rising sales in 1991. The rest will see no growth or suffer a drop in sales. ``The outlook is generally one of continuing but slow growth for most sectors (of the economy),'' said Commerce Undersecretary J. Michael Farren. However, the department's forecasts are based on an assumption that the economy will avoid a recession with a growth in the gross national product next year in the lower end of a 1 percent to 3 percent range. Nearly all private economists contend the economy already is shrinking and will continue to do so at least through the first quarter of 1991 with an annual growth in GNP of around 0.3 percent next year. The Commerce Department report said that overall the median growth rate for manufacturing sales is expected to be positive for the ninth consecutive year, but by a barely perceptible 0.89 percent, down from an almost-as-dismal 0.95 percent this year. The median rate - the point where half of the industries had bigger sales increases and half had smaller - was far healthier in 1988, 2.1 percent, and 1987, 3 percent. The 560-page report, ``U.S. Industrial Outlook,'' was prepared by 130 analysts using information current through August and September. Retail sales were projected to rise only 1 or 2 percent after inflation next year. ``Consumer-oriented industries are expected to do less well overall, reflecting the general slowdown in the economy,'' Farren said. ``Such products as furniture, appliances and household audio and video equipment are expected to decline.'' Two key sectors of the economy, construction and motor vehicles, were expected to have another bad year in 1991, with their weakness spilling over into a variety of related industries. High vacancy rates in office buildings was expected to depress construction by 15 percent, while hotel construction was predicted to fall 20 percent. Residential housing construction was expected to decline 6 percent from 1.22 million units to 1.15 million. Car sales probably will fall from 9.5 million this year to 9.3 million, but truck sales likely will rise about 1 percent to 4.7 million, the report said. ``The declines in both construction and motor vehicles will have a significant impact on a number of other major industries, including building materials, household durables (goods such as appliances that are expected to last three or more years), steel and wood products,'' Farren said. In addition to the manufacturing industries, the report also evaluated 166 service businesses, the fastest-growing sector of the economy. However, Farren cautioned that the performance of services was much more difficult to forecast and to compare to previous years. Electronic information services, computer software and other computer services are expected to do the best, while slower expansion was projected for movie theaters, home entertainment and legal services. In manufacturing, most of the 10 fastest-growing industries are connected with either health care or high-technology. Leather tanning and finishing topped the list, with 9.4 percent expected growth. But that was considered an anomaly largely attributed to expected increases in domestic production because of new duties imposed on leather imports from Argentina. Leather tanning was followed by semiconductors, the basic building block of computer chips, with a projected 8.9 percent increase in sales, and surgical instruments, up 8.6 percent. Others in the top 10 were surgical supplies, medicines, diagnostic substances, poultry slaughtering and processing, biological products, aircraft and dental equipment. At the bottom of the scale was creamery butter, with a projected sales decline of 14.6 percent. The department attributed the drop to consumers' worry about cholesterol and weight gain. Other shrinking industries were mobile homes, frozen baked goods except bread, boat building, motors and generators, household cooking equipment, hardwood and flooring mills, electric housewares and fans, fabricated metal, and sawmill and planing mills. In general, the department said industries linked to export sales would fare better than businesses tied to the domestic economy. Farren said foreigners will be encouraged to buy U.S. goods by the decline in the value of the dollar this year. However, Farren conceded that the price of oil, driven up by the Persian Gulf crisis, likely would keep the U.S. trade deficit, $109.4 billion in 1989, at about $105 billion in 1990 as well as next year. The report predicted continued business investment, despite the slow economy as manufacturers try to keep up with overseas competitors and meet new environmental requirements, requiring new pollution-control equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Last Decade of the Century Begins, Finally
DOC.TEXT: When does a new decade begin, anyway? We ushered in the '90s a year ago, but the last decade of the 20th Century is only now about to unfold. Confused? Well, you can thank a monk named Dionysius Exiguus. He started it all many hundreds of years ago. The question surfaces every 10 years and for many people the answer is obvious: the new decades began with the 1990s a year ago on Jan. 1, 1990 and will end Dec. 31, 1999. But don't tell that to the calendar purists. ``If you refer to the decade of the '90s, I'm willing to concede that 1990 is in the '90s. It's obviously not in the '80s,'' says LeRoy Doggett, a calendar expert at the U.S. Naval Observatory. But he explains that this view of a decade in time is simply a colloquialism with no basis in history. ``When we talk about the last decade of the 20th century we get into a chronological question which forces you to ask: When did the first century begin?'' he says. Doggett provides this explanation. The numbering system in our current Gregorian calendar, indeed in all human calendars, is arbitrary. Someone picked a particular date or event and started counting from that point. There is nothing in nature that causes it to be a particular year, or for a particular day to be New Year. That's where the monk Dionysius Exiguus, or ``Dennis the Small'', got into the act nearly 1,500 years ago. He had been given the task of developing a set of tables to help local priests and bishops determine the date of Easter. At the time, everything was dated from the accession of the Roman emperor Diocletian. But Diocletian had persecuted the early Christians and Dionysius didn't want to commemorate him in the new tables. Instead Dionysius based the tables on the date of Jesus' birth, which the monk determined had occurred 532 years earlier. Dionysius called the year of Jesus' birth the year ``1'' and began the count. ``So the first decade was 1 to 10, the second was 11 to 20. Extrapolating from that, we end up starting a new decade with 1991, which runs through 2000, which completes the 20th century. So the 21st century starts with 2001,'' said Doggett. Why didn't Dionysius simply call the first year ``zero'' and avoid all the confusion? ``Well, the number zero was not then in use in the West,'' explained Doggett. Counting was done using either Roman Numerals or fingers, neither of which includes a zero. There's more. Many scholars have concluded that Dionysius actually miscalculated by two to 10 years the actual birth of Jesus. But by the time those questions were raised, his numbering system was widely used and was not changed. And the year 1991 is not the only year that makes its debut in the coming 12 months. The Muslim year 1412 begins at sundown next July 12 and the Jewish year 5752 begins at sundown next Sept. 8.

DOC.HEAD: After Years of War and Occupation, Hope Eludes Many Cambodians
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Peu Dinda, hopping up a hill on one leg with rusty crutches, says life won't improve for him no matter who controls Cambodia. He is one of the thousands to have lost a part of themselves during Cambodia's 20-year-old civil war. In this Southeast Asian country where most people work two or even three jobs to survive, the former soldier can't find any job at all. Without any formal education, he said his only hope is manual labor. But with only one leg, he fears that's an impossibility. ``It's difficult to tell the future,'' said Peu Dinda, who survives on a meager government war stipend. Such feelings of hopelessness grip many Cambodians. Since gaining independence from the French in 1954, this country has struggled to survive American bombings, a superpower-sponsored civil war, a Khmer Rouge genocide and an 11-year Vietnamese occupation. Promises of peace and prosperity with the next government are greeted with wariness - and weariness. World leaders have called a peace settlement by Cambodia's four warring groups the long sought-after solution to the country's problems. They say a Sept. 10 agreement to share power in a Supreme National Council - supervised by the United Nations - is what the country needs. Signing the accord is the Vietnam-installed government of Prime Minister Hun Sen and a coalition that includes the Khmer Rouge, Khmer People's National Liberation Front and forces of former Cambodian leader Prince Norodom Sihanouk. The council is meant to be a symbolic government, with the United Nations running the country, organizing a cease-fire, planning elections, ending all foreign military aid and disarming the four groups fighting for power. But the groups have broken peace agreements in the past. Meanwhile, the country is stagnating. Boys march into Phnom Penh's best restaurants to beg food off the plates of foreigners. A mother washes her month-old baby under water dripping from a fire hydrant. The bulk of Cambodia's property is so run down that it can't be rented. Electricity and running water are a luxury; some people carry buckets of water to their homes up flights of stairs daily. There are no official records of the country's per capita income or unemployment rate, according to Cambodia's mission to the United Nations in New York. Said the mission's First Secretary, P. Cheng: ``All of the social structure is basically destroyed. Statistics are not possible.'' The World Almanac Book of Facts in 1990 cites six-year-old statistics as its most recent, listing $100 as the per capita income in 1984. Some blame Cambodia's troubles on its history as a political pawn. The country has been at the mercy of outside powers like China, the Soviet Union and the United States for years. ``American policymakers look at Cambodia through an empty Vietnamese glass. It is not how to help Cambodia but how to punish Vietnam,'' said Khieu Kanharith, former editor of a weekly state-owned newspaper. Khieu was referring to the U.S. trade restrictions imposed against Cambodia because of its 11-year occupation by Vietnam. ``The international boycott is keeping us from progressing. The only one way for us to catch up with our neighboring countries is with international aid,'' Khieu said. Further evidence of a country trapped in the past is just inside the National Pedriatric Hospital, the country's showcase hospital. Dr. Chour Ymeng, the hospital's vice director, pointed to the sick people lining hallway floors. He showed a visitor the red blotches dotting a baby - caused by malnutrition, which is easily preventable. Chour said he is one of only a handful of doctors who survived the Khmer Rouge killing fields. If more doctors had lived, perhaps more children could be saved today, he said. Chour isn't the only one who thinks about what could have been. The brother of Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot has spent years picturing life without the genocidal group. Loth Suong lives in a rundown housing project without electricity to power his refrigerator, a television or even lights. His brother lives in a Thai beach villa and has yet to be brought to justice for his genocidal rule. ``My brother brought Cambodia down. If the country has no Khmer Rouge, ordinary people will have a good living standard,'' said Loth, 79. ``Because I am old, I need only peace. Now I call for you to give peace to Cambodia.'' Ros Sopea, a 29-year-old journalism student at Phnom Penh University, said there aren't enough social services such as schools or hospitals in Cambodia. But she said Cambodia would develop quickly if only the war would end, freeing the country's estimated 6 million people to produce enough rice to get ahead. Not everyone has Ros' faith. Lim Sothy fled Cambodia several months ago. Clutching an English dictionary, the 18-year-old headed for a refugee camp just inside Thailand. When last seen, he had about 215 miles, fields of landmines and border guards to get past. But Lim said he had nothing to lose.

DOC.HEAD: Love Your Legislator Day Planned For Wisconsin Churches
DOC.TEXT: As if politicians didn't find enough opportunities to speak their minds, a man wants people to show appreciation for their public officials by offering them a pulpit. Steven Trueblood is urging 500 Wisconsin churches to declare Jan. 13 ``Love Your Legislator Day.'' ``We're asking the churches to invite legislators to the Sunday service, give them a few minutes to express their views on public issues and then have a session after the service where church members can go up to their legislators and thank them for their service,'' Trueblood said. Trueblood, who describes himself as a former felon and drug dealer, is director of the Freedom Council of America, a Janesville group that provides volunteer chaplain services to the Wisconsin and Illinois legislatures. He said he became a born-again Christian in 1982 and was later pardoned by Gov. Tommy G. Thompson. ``After the scandal of Watergate, it seems like we lost complete respect for the position these people serve in,'' Trueblood said. ``The public service arena is filled with dedicated, hard-working people who deserve to be honored for the position they hold.''

DOC.HEAD: People In The News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Bob Hope, back from the Persian Gulf region, says the morale of troops in Operation Desert Shield is high and they're ready for action. The 87-year-old entertainer said in a telephone interview from his home Saturday that the GIs wildly appreciated his efforts and those of the troupe of entertainers that included Marie Osmond, Ann Jillian, the Pointer Sisters and his wife, Dolores. ``It was just exciting as hell,'' Hope said. ``The morale is immense. It was just great. They're just all ready.'' Hope said the only woman allowed to venture into the desert, because of Saudi restrictions on women, was his wife, who sang ``White Christmas.'' The other female performers did shows on warships and for the finale Thursday in the tiny island nation of Bahrain. --- DALLAS (AP) - Actor Martin Sheen turned autograph hound after wrapping up a scene in The Dallas Morning News newsroom for an upcoming miniseries. Sheen, who plays a Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter in ``Touch and Die,'' found himself talking last week to real-life Pulitzer winner David Hanners, whose winning 1988 story detailed the investigation of a private airplane crash in poor weather. Sheen asked for an autograph, and Hanners penned: ``To Martin: Don't fly when it rains.'' Sheen, 50, is playing the lead in the miniseries, which is a project of Italian, French, German and British producers. The movie depicts Sheen on the trail of a presidential candidate campaigning with tainted funds. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Anti-war activist Ron Kovic joined hundreds of others in a demonstration urging President Bush to set a date for talks in the Persian Gulf crisis. ``I don't want to see another Vietnam in the Persian Gulf,'' said Kovic, whose autobiography ``Born on the Fourth of July'' and the film made from it described his fight to overcome paralyzing war wounds. ``We don't want our men and women to die in a senseless war,'' he said Saturday outside the Westwood federal building. ``This (conflict) is not about naked aggression, it's about oil.'' Kovic estimated that 1,200 protesters appeared at the noon-hour rally, but a federal building security guard said only 200 demonstrated. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Rookie Boston Celtics guard Dee Brown III married Jill Edmondson in a 10-minute private service witnessed fellow Celtic Robert Parish. The couple took their brief vows Saturday in a chapel of Wellesley Hills Congregational Church. Edmondson's mother, Lisa Grames, and brother, Mark Bryant, attended the ceremony along with Parish and an unidentified escort. Brown, 22, and Edmondson, 25, plan to live in Wellesley. Last September, when the couple were looking for a home in the town, several police officers mistook Brown, who is black, for a bank robber and forced the couple out of their car at gunpoint. The police department in the largely white suburb later apologized. --- DALLAS (AP) - A Mississippi woman has been selected the 1991 Maid of Cotton to preside over Cotton Bowl events and spend six months as a goodwill ambassador for the U.S. cotton industry. Meg Williams, 22, a native of Tupelo and graduate of Vanderbilt University, edged out finalists from 11 other states Saturday to earn the National Cotton Council honor. She is the 54th Maid of Cotton. As Maid of Cotton, Ms. Williams earns a $10,000 educational scholarship and will make her first appearance at the Cotton Bowl parade on New Year's Day. She is majoring in interior design at the Parsons School of Design in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Screenwriter Warren Skaaren Dies At 44
DOC.TEXT: Warren Skaaren, a screenwriter who worked on such blockbusters as ``Batman'' and ``Top Gun,'' has died of bone cancer. He was 44. Skaaren died at home Friday night. He learned how severe his condition was early this summer, shortly after completing his last screenplay, ``Beetlejuice 2,'' said W. Amon Burton, his attorney and friend. During the 1980s, Skaaren gained a reputation as one of the country's top script doctors - a screenwriter who could take over a troubled script and rewrite it. The four films he was best known for rewriting - ``Batman,'' ``Top Gun,'' ``Beverly Hills Cop 2'' and ``Beetlejuice'' - together grossed more than $1 billion. ``He understood what the audience needed to have in a story,'' said Mike Simpson, Skaaren's agent and senior vice president of the William Morris Agency's motion picture department. ``He could see the big picture. He had an almost scientific ability to analyze characters and what their motivation was, and what the audience wanted and what it expected from those characters,'' Simpson said. A native of Rochester, Minn., Skaaren attended Rice University in Houston. He graduated with an art degree in 1969. Although he rose quickly through the ranks of Hollywood screenwriters, he chose to live in Austin rather than Southern California. He founded the Texas Film Commission and became its first director in 1971 while working for then-Gov. Preston Smith. In the mid-1970s, Skaaren helped form FPS Inc., a television and film productions services company in Dallas. The company has handled location shooting for the television series ``Dallas,'' and worked on the film ``Tender Mercies,'' which was shot in Waxahachie. Skaaren is survived by his wife, Helen, and his parents, Morris and Pearl Skaaren of Rochester, Minn. His body will be cremated in a private service, but a public memorial service will be scheduled in the next two weeks, Burton said.

DOC.HEAD: Hijackers Surrender, Ending Hostage Standoff
LaserPhoto PAR5,6
DOC.TEXT: Two army deserters who hijacked a domestic airliner surrendered on Sunday, freeing the last of dozens of hostages and ending a two-day standoff, officials reported. The jetliner's pilot said the two hijackers themselves didn't seem to know why on Friday they had commandeered the Air Algerie Boeing 737 carrying 88 people from the Saharan town of Ghardaia to Algiers. The plane was forced to land in the eastern city of Annaba. The hijackers handed their firearms over to police shortly after dawn following negotiations with the interior minister, the state news agency APS reported. The two, identified as deserters from Ghardaia, then were whisked away in a police car to an undisclosed location. ``I'm very happy with the happy outcome of this affair,'' APS quoted Interior Minister Saleh Mohammedi as saying. ``The authors of this hijacking ... will be prosecuted.'' Their ages were listed as 22 and 23, but their names were not disclosed and their motivation remained a mystery to their captives. ``It's something I just wasn't successful in bringing up, and I had a lot of leisure time to discuss with them,'' said Capt. Salim Zemti, one of the two final hostages released. ``They seemed ignorant themselves of the reason behind what they were doing,'' Zemti said. But he added they may have been ``exasperated with their living conditions and decided to hijack a plane on the spur of the moment.'' Zemti said the pair first demanded to be flown to Tripoli, Libya, but the plane lacked fuel for the trip. They settled for Carthage in Tunisia, but Tunisian authorities refused them permission to land. They finally touched down Saturday in Annaba, near the Algeria-Tunisia border. Zemti and passengers reported no ill-treatment. Local officials in Ghardaia said the two deserted their base Friday and ran 14 miles to the airport before hijacking the Algiers-bound flight. They speculated the hijacking may have been an attempt to escape prosecution for desertion. Passengers said the pair spoke little and used varying regional accents in an apparent effort to mask their identities. Transport Minister Hassan Kahlouche and passengers said the hijackers made no statements to support reports they were protesting a crackdown on Islamic fundamentalists in neighboring Tunisia. One passenger said the hijackers ``broke into laughter'' on hearing such a report Saturday on Algerian radio. ``Right now, this only concerns a simple affair of common law,'' APS quoted Kahlouche as saying. Air Algerie said at least 14 passengers aboard the plane were foreigners. Algerian and Western officials said they included French, German, Italian, British and Japanese nationals. Most of the foreigners were freed on Saturday. The breakthrough came after dawn on Sunday. The hijackers announced they would free most of the remaining 52 captives, but planned to hold the pilot and co-pilot and renewed demands for fuel to fly to another country. The interior minister approached the plane and finalized the release of the captives, witnesses said. After they disembarked, he then persuaded the hijackers to give up. Various reports during the negotiations said the hijackers had demanded water and enough fuel to fly to Egypt or Libya. Egyptian officials said their airports had been ordered to refuse them permission to land. There was no comment available from Libya.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavian Parliament Agrees to Gorbachev's Measures
DOC.TEXT: Moldavia, acting to defuse one of the Soviet Union's most explosive ethnic conflicts, agreed Sunday to comply with a Kremlin order to reconsider its law making Moldavian the republic's official language. The republic's parliament acted in response to a decree issued on Dec. 22 by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the official news agency Tass reported. Gorbachev also gave the republic 10 days to dissolve a new national guard and to come up with measures guaranteeing equal rights for all ethnic groups within its borders. Tass said the Moldavan parliament agreed to disband the nationalguard and to revise a law that Gorbachev said restricted the rights of minorities. Ethnic tension has gripped Moldavia, a largely agricultural republic bordering Romania, during its push for independence from the Soviet Union this year. The unrest turned violent last month, when government troops clashed with activists, leaving four dead. Gorbachev said the conflicts had reached ``critical levels,'' and he put part of the blame on the Moldavian Supreme Soviet for enacting laws that discriminate against minorities. Alarmed by rising Moldavian nationalism, two of the republic's minority groups have begun their own separatist movements. The Gagauz, a group of about 150,000 Turkish Christians, declared a new republic in southern Moldavia. In the eastern part of Moldavia, more than 300,000 ethnic Russians and Ukrainians have joined in declaring a new republic along the Dneister River. All three groups claim discrimination by Moldavians. In particular, they resent a new law making Moldavian the official language and requiring people in dozens of jobs ranging from doctors to hairdressers to pass Moldavian language tests by 1995. Tass did not say how the Moldavian parliament would modify the law. Moldavian is identical to Romanian except for the Cyrillic script Josef Stalin imposed on the republic. It is spoken by two-thirds of the republic's residents. Soviet hard-liners want Gorbachev to impose a state of emergency and presidential rule in troubled zones throughout the ethnically and geographically diverse country. Gorbachev said the declaration of the Gagauz and Dniester republics was illegal under the Soviet and Moldavian constitutions, as were elections to form legislatures and any actions by those bodies. The Moldavian legislature has also voted to declare the elections null and void. After residents of the Gagauz region began holding local elections in late October, the Moldavian legislature clamped a two-month state of emergency on the region, restricting movement in and out of the area and banning public rallies. Volunteer brigades of college-age Moldavians, who then flocked to the region to try to stop the separatist movement, were ordered dissolved by Gorbachev's decree. The volunteers were organized by nationalist groups, including the Moldavian People's Front.
