DOC.HEAD: Quayle Talks With Saudis, Seeks More Money for Military Effort
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle told Saudi King Fahd on Sunday that the United States expects more financial support from the oil-rich nation for U.S. military efforts against Iraq and the Arab ruler seemed to agree, U.S. officials said. They said no figures were mentioned in the two-hour meeting, but that U.S. officials left with the impression there will be no problem getting more money with the Saudis. ``They have been forthcoming on that subject,'' said one senior administration official. ``The impression that was left was that they would continue to be forthcoming. They don't want any perception of any reluctance on that issue.'' Quayle, who was not available to reporters after the late night meeting, had said in advance that he intended to tell Saudi leaders ``they will have to be making more contributions.'' The vice president's three-day visit began just 16 days before the United Nations-imposed Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq to withdraw its troops from Kuwait or face possible war.. The U.S. official, who discussed the Quayle-Fahd meeting on condition of not being identified by name, said the two were ``in virtually complete agreement on what needed to be done'' in terms of forcing Iraq out of Kuwait. ``There was no reticence'' on Fahd's part to the idea of launching a war against Iraq if President Saddam Hussein does not withdraw, the official said. The official said Quayle also assured Fahd that, despite reluctance expressed by some members of Congress, ``President Bush would have the latitude to do what he felt he had to do,'' after Jan. 15 - including a military strike. Quayle met separately with Fahd and the Saudi deputy prime minister, Crown Prince Abdullah, shortly after his arrival. He planned to meet with Kuwait's exile emir on Tuesday after a New Year's Day visit to some of the more than 300,000 U.S. troops in the region. The Pentagon previously has projected the cost of Operation Desert Shield, as the deployment is called, at $8.2 billion through the end of 1990. The costs are expected to increase, however, because of the additional troops currently being deployed. A full-scale shooting war has been estimated to cost as much as $1 billion to $2 billion a day. ``You are seeing other nations making contributions .. I will thank (the Saudis and Kuwaitis) for the contributions they have made thus far, but point out that more contributions will have to be made ... because the crisis is going to continue,'' said Quayle. So far, Saudi Arabia has contributed $9 billion, nearly half of it in cash and the rest in military support for U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia, according to the State Department. Kuwait has given $2.5 billion, U.S. officials said. Saudi Arabia also has spent $3.9 billion and Kuwait $3.3 billion to help countries such as Turkey and Egypt that have suffered severe economic repercussions from the U.N.-imposed economic sanctions against Iraq. Quayle will spend much of New Year's Day visiting with U.S. troops in the gulf. Among those deployed to the region are units of the Indiana National Guard in which Quayle served during the Vietnam War. He was later embroiled in controversy over whether he used family connections to get into the Guard unit rather than risk being drafted and sent to Vietnam. Asked about President Bush's comment to Time magazine that he has a ``gut feeling'' Saddam Hussein will withdraw by the deadline, Quayle said he was not as optimistic. ``I hope he does. But I certainly do not see any information that he will do so. Saddam Hussein has always done the unexpected ... let's hope he does the unexpected again,'' said Quayle. But he added, ``if force is required, it will be swift, it will be massive, it will be certain.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Blocks Father From Moving Daughter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead making `fuss' to legal strife.
DOC.TEXT: The father of a brain-damaged patient at the hospital where Nancy Cruzan was allowed to die after a court fight has been blocked from moving his daughter to a state where her feeding tube could be removed with less legal strife. Pete Busalacchi says his daughter, Christine, should be allowed to die. But Don Lamkins, director of the Missouri Rehabilitation Center, contends Ms. Busalacchi has mental functions and responds to commands. Ms. Busalacchi, 20, has spent 3{ years in a vegetative state similar to that of Ms. Cruzan, who was buried Friday after becoming a focus of national debate and a landmark U.S. Supreme Court ruling on the right to die. The case renewed warnings Sunday from euthanasia opponents that a ``tidal wave'' of death for hopeless patients would result from the Cruzan case. Lamkins said Sunday that the 10-day restraining order issued Saturday will give doctors time to examine Ms. Busalacchi. Lawrence County Judge Scott Sifferman scheduled a Jan. 8 hearing to hear results of the tests. There are parallels in the Cruzan and Busalacchi cases. Both young women suffered severe brain damage in car crashes. Their parents contended there was no sign of recognition, pain or emotion in either patient. And neither left written instructions about being kept alive in case of debilitating illness or injury. Busalacchi said Sunday that he was angry and frustrated about the legal action. ``My feeling is my daughter died a long time ago, and all that's left is just a machine,'' Busalacchi said from his home in St. Charles, Mo., a suburb of St. Louis. Busalacchi said he had hired a lawyer and planned to fight. ``I will not see my daughter held prisoner in Missouri,'' he said. The U.S. Supreme Court, ruling in its first right-to-die case, said June 25 that Missouri could require ``clear and convincing'' evidence that Ms. Cruzan, 33, would not want to be kept alive in her vegetative state. Her relatives returned to state court with three witnesses whose testimony led to a judge's permission to remove Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube on Dec. 14. She died 12 days later. Busalacchi said he spoke Sunday morning with Ms. Cruzan's father, Joe, who ``told me to be strong and offered to help in any way he could.'' Busalacchi expected to move Christine on Saturday to Minneapolis, where specialists were to decide whether her tube should be removed under state provisions that recognize ethical decisions by doctors. Dr. Ronald Cranford of Hennepin County Medical Center in Minneapolis, one of Ms. Busalacchi's doctors, said Saturday it would be the first case he knew in which a person was transferred from a state with a highly restrictive right-to-die law to another state to allow removal of life-support equipment. Cranford, a neurologist and medical ethicist who has been a consultant in the Busalacchi case, said Ms Busalacci is incapable of any conscious thoughts or deliberate actions. The finding is based on the medical records and his personal observations. In an affidavit filed with the judge Saturday, Lamkins said there was ``scientific and observational evidence'' that Ms. Busalacchi was ``cognitive of her surroundings and does have some mental functions.'' He said that on Dec. 19, on a nurse's command, the young woman waved at him. ``She waved only one finger. When the nurse said `You can do better than that,' or words to that effect, Christine Busalacchi waved at me with all her fingers, clearly aware of what was said to her and of her surroundings.'' The father rejected Lamkins' observations. ``Yes, her fingers can move. But it doesn't happen on command. It doesn't happen with consistency,'' he said. ``They also say she can smile at you, but it's no smile that you or I would recognize.'' Activists raised protests Sunday. ``Certainly this has set off the tidal wave we warned about, since there is no clear and convincing evidence in Christine's case that she would want to die,'' Rita Marker, director of the International Anti-Euthanasia Task Force, said Sunday from Steubenville, Ohio. ``We have to realize that much of this debate has to do with relieving the family of a burden,'' she said. Kay S. Dowhower, Washington-based director of governmental affairs for the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America, said Sunday that denominations which supported the Cruzans should also sympathize with Busalacchi, who in the early 1970s had to decide to take his terminally ill wife off life-support equipment. The Evangelical Lutherans joined four other major denominations in supporting the Cruzans.

DOC.HEAD: Boy's 6-Foot Ninja Turtle Stolen
DOC.TEXT: A $50 reward is being offered for the safe return of Michelangelo - a 6-foot wooden Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtle last seen wishing passersby a merry Christmas. Four-year-old David Moor's life-size statue was stolen just before Christmas. ``I felt sad,'' David said. ``Maybe the policeman will find it for me and bring it back.'' Rex Gash, David's neighbor and a carpenter, said it took him four days to cut the wood and paint the replica of the character. ``I didn't know what a Mutant Ninja Turtle looked like before I did this,'' Gash said. ``I watched the movie one night and made sketches the next day.'' Gash said he gave David the statue about a week before Christmas. ``He was just as excited as he could be,'' Gash said. ``He was jumping up and down.'' David and his mother, Nancy Moor, put the statue with a holiday greeting outside their home and it was stolen a few days later. Witnesses said they saw a car speed away with it. Gash is offering the reward.

DOC.HEAD: Panama's President Clashes With Parliament Over Security Agency
DOC.TEXT: President Guillermo Endara has rejected the National Assembly's callfor an investigation of a new security agency that he reportedly set up with help from the CIA and without legislative approval. The assembly on Saturday created a commission to investigate the Council of Public Security and National Defense. It also criticized Endara for ``disrespectful and excessive'' treatment of a deputy who questioned his creation of the agency without legislative approval. The Miami Herald and the Washington Post reported recently that Panama formed an intelligence agency with help from the CIA and the Taiwanese and Venezuelan security services. Endara late Saturday accused the lawmakers of ``trying to meddle in matters which are the private affairs of the executive branch.'' ``It seems that some legislators are interested in getting rid of a service of security and defense information which reports directly to the president,'' Endara said. He denied that the new council, created by executive order in February, was involved in espionage. A Dec. 25 Washington Post story said the agency was created in July, had 100 members and was being established with the help of the CIA. Many Panamanians are suspicious of the agency, the Post reported, because the CIA also once maintained a relationship with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The strongman was overthrown in last December's U.S. invasion. The story said the agency's director was Menalco Solis, a former law partner of Endara who was also treasury minister in Noriega's puppet civilian government in 1984-85.

DOC.HEAD: Fire in Philippines Hotel Kills Three American Servicemen
DOC.TEXT: Fire swept through a two-story hotel packed with U.S. servicemen en route to the Persian Gulf on Sunday, and police said three Americans and a Filipino woman were killed. Two other Americans were injured in the fire, which broke out about 1:30 a.m. at the 34-room, two-story Royal Lodge Hotel, one of many around the Subic Bay naval base filled with sailors shipping out to the gulf. Mike Pusing, spokesman for the city government, said the cause had not been determined but arson was suspected. Investigators said one of the dead was an enlisted man assigned to the aircraft carrier USS Ranger, part of a convoy that arrived at Subic Bay from San Diego on Thursday on its way to the gulf. The other American victims also were believed assigned to the task force, the largest to sail from the west coast of the United States since World War II. The U.S. Navy withheld the names of the dead pending notification of relatives. U.S. Embassy spokesman Stanley Schrager said the two injured were in stable condition at the base hospital. Witnesses said dozens of Americans fled the hotel in their nightclothes. The hotel is about a mile from the main gate at Subic, which is about 50 miles west of Manila, Pusing said.

DOC.HEAD: Argentines Bitterly Divided on Pardons
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with crowd estimate of 40,000 sted 15,000; DELETES 6th pvs `The pardons...' as redundant; pickup graf 9 pvs ```We here...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BAI1
DOC.TEXT: About 40,000 Argentines rallied outside President Carlos Menem's office Sunday to protest his pardon of key figures who served in the military dictatorship during the 1970s ``dirty war'' on leftists. Menem's action Saturday revealed a nation still bitterly divided over a painful period of its history. Roman Catholic Bishop Jaime de Nevares said the pardons mocked justice, broke the law and trampled on human rights. Another church leader, Archbishop Antonio Quarracino, said they were necessary and ``make me happy.'' The two rival factions of the General Labor Federation, Argentina's major labor group, were also divided. Recent polls showed up to 80 percent of Argentines opposed the pardons. The pardons included Mario Firmenich, 42-year-old co-founder of the Montonero terrorist movement; and former Presidents Jorge Videla, 65, and Roberto Viola, 66, who ruled the country from the 1976 coup until 1982; and nine other officials. Sunday afternoon, about 40,000 people - a cross-section of ages, income levels, political parties and professions - gathered outside Menem's office waving banners and angrily denouncing the pardons. ``We're here to tell him that we haven't forgotten what happened, and we won't forget,'' said protester Daniel Sossa. He said his aunt was arrested during the 1976-83 dictatorship and never heard from again. Menem, himself jailed without charge during the period, told reporters: ``They can have all the marches they want. ... That doesn't bother me. I believe it was best for my country. Period.'' Videla, freed Saturday after more than five years in prison, attended Mass at a chapel near his apartment Sunday and handed reporters a short statement that said in part: ``I ask God to extinguish forever the hatred among Argentines with the goal that we all may reconcile ourselves in peace, union and liberty.'' Viola, Videla and six other senior officers were pardoned for crimes including torture, illegal detention and murder. Former finance minister Jose Martinez de Hoz and two former civilian officials, all of whom had been jailed on other charges, were included in the pardon. Menem said the pardons, by ending a justification for military restiveness, would allow Argentina to look ahead. But many said they merely reopened wounds. ``The pardons do not leave the past behind, but take us back to the worst failures of our past,'' said former President Raul Alfonsin, leader of the main opposition party, the Radical Civic Union. ``This is the saddest day in Argentine history,'' he said. Urban terrorist attacks in the 1970s and the military junta's heavy-handed response still wrench Argentina's national psyche seven years after the return to democracy with Alfonsin's election in October 1983. Menem was elected last year. Alfonsin and the Congress gave amnesty to hundreds of lower-ranking officers, after three military uprisings against his government to protest pending trials of soldiers accused of rights abuses. A fourth rebellion to protest Videla's imprisonment was crushed by the government Dec. 3. Menem had earlier promised the military that the pardons were in the works. The military insists it was forced to use unconventional methods to stop the leftist guerrillas. Many claim the military used the insurgency as a pretext for repression. At least 8,960 alleged leftists disappeared and were presumed executed. Human rights put the death toll at about 30,000.

DOC.HEAD: Punk Fans Rampage in Los Angeles, Rap Fans Brawl in Chicago
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS typo in `anti-Semitism' in last graf.
DOC.TEXT: Punk rock fans ordered to leave an overcrowded concert hall went on a rampage, ripping out seats, hurling bottles at police and smashing the windows of stores and offices outside, authorities said Sunday. A police officer was cut on the head by a bottle and several concertgoers were injured in the Saturday night melee at the Classic Theater in North Hollywood, officials said. Firefighters briefly turned hoses on the crowd to restore order. Three people were arrested, one for vandalism, one for an alcohol-related offense and another on a felony warrant. Assistant Fire Chief Jim Mullen said nearly 1,900 people had jammed into the theater, several hundred more than its capacity, and fire officials ordered it closed at about 8:30 p.m. ``I've been doing this for 10 years and as soon as I saw the police and their truncheons, I knew the show was over,'' said Peter Firestone, drummer for the show's headline act, Bad Religion. Most fans left quietly when ordered to, but a brawl erupted and about 200 seats were damaged in an ensuing rampage, Mullen said. Some fans started a fire in a trash can on the second floor, but it was quickly put out, he said. Outside, fans smashed windows in shops, offices and a bank building. Property damage was estimated by police at about $20,000. Concert producer Bryan Meckelborg said 1,325 tickets had been sold to the event. Meanwhile, in Chicago, police and concertgoers clashed after a Saturday night performance by the rap group Public Enemy. Five people, including four officers, were injured and 18 arrests were made. The melee began early Sunday after the concert at the Aragon Ballroom on the city's north side ended. Several anti-war demonstrators began speaking into a bullhorn across the street from the concert hall, protesting the United States' military buildup in the Persian Gulf in response to Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. ``They began chanting anti-war slogans so, of course, the people started to listen,'' said police Lt. Paul Lewis. ``The more people came out, the more traffic built up, until finally it was stopped in all directions and the officers asked (the protesters) to stop using the bullhorn until it was cleared,'' he said. ``At that point, the crowd began throwing things and soe of them jumped into the fray.'' Lewis said he didn't know how large the crowd was. The 15 men and three women arrested were charged with mob action and released. Court dates were set for Jan. 29. Public Enemy recordings have been banned in some cities because of charges of anti-Semitism and violence in the lyrics.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Leaders Urge Bush to Redouble Effort to Avoid War. ^EDS: Subs 24th graf prv, ``Vice President xxx with two grafs, now beginning ``Meanwhile, aides xxx to update with Quayle meeting results
DOC.TEXT: Congressional leaders said Sunday the White House should redouble its efforts to find a peaceful solution to the crisis in the Persian Gulf because the American people don't want to fight a war in the region. ``The American people are not yet committed to war, and they want to make certain that President Bush has done everything, pursued every avenue for peace before the firing starts,'' said Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press.'' ``The American people do not want war,'' he said. Both Dole and Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, said Bush and Iraqi President Saddam Hussein must break the stalemate over diplomatic talks between the two countries. Dole said he has received indications from Iraq that Saddam may be willing to show flexibility on dates for the talks. ``People want to make sure that we've tried every other alternative before going to war, that we tried to solve this every other way,'' Aspin said on CBS-TV's ``Face the Nation.'' ``A diplomatic effort really needs to be made and has to be made before the decision to go to war,'' he said. With the U.N. security council's Jan. 15 deadline for Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait drawing closer, Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., predicted a ``real intensification of diplomatic effort in the next few days.'' Hamilton, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Europe and the Middle East, also appeared on the CBS program. Hamilton and Dole expressed optimism about a peaceful solution to the crisis. ``My gut tells me that there will be a resolution (of the crisis) without firing a shot,'' Dole said. Added Hamilton: ``There are some straws there that indicate a diplomatic solution may work.'' He cited fresh appeals by Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher for a new diplomatic effort to try to avoid war. ``People are very, very nervous about the outbreak of war,'' Hamilton said. The lawmakers' comments complemented Bush's remark in a Time magazine interview, to be published Monday, in which he said he has a ``gut feeling'' that Saddam will withdraw from Kuwait. Top Democratic and GOP congressional leaders will meet with Bush on Thursday, the day that the new Congress convenes. Aspin said congressional leaders are going to demand to know if Bush intends to ask Congress for war-making authority before he uses force in the gulf. ``I think that's a very, very important thing that they (the administration) commit to do that, that we do have a vote on that in Congress,'' he said. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., on Saturday suggested Democrats might try to cut off money for Operation Desert Shield if Bush goes to war without seeking congressional authority. Gephardt said U.N. sanctions against Iraq should be given at least 18 months to work. But in a prelude to partisan wrangling over the issue, Dole called Gephardt's proposal ``incredible'' and declared: ``I'd like him to tell that to the troops in the sands of Saudi Arabia.'' The Senate's ranking GOP member predicted neither the Democrat-controlled House or Senate would approve such a resolution. ``That was a big, big political mistake,'' said Dole of Gephardt's remark. Dole also said the anti-Iraq coalition would likely fall apart if the United States waited 12 months to 18 months for sanctions to work. Aspin repeated his skepticism about sanctions. ``I'm not very bullish on sanctions,'' he said. But Dole agreed with Gephardt that America's allies, Japan and Germany, should pay a larger share of the cost of maintaining more than 300,000 U.S. troops in Saudi Arabia. Meanwhile, aides to Vice President Dan Quayle said he told Saudi King Fahd in a Sunday evening meeting in Riyadh that the United States expects more financial support from the oil-rich nation for U.S. military efforts against Iraq and that the Arab ruler seemed to agree. ``They have been forthcoming on that subject,'' said one senior administration official. ``The impression that was left was that they would continue to be forthcoming. They don't want any perception of any reluctance on that issue.'' Unless members of Congress vote to stay in session specifically to tackle the gulf issue, the lawmakers are expected to deal mostly with formalities when they meet this week before going home until after Jan. 20. Dole said lawmakers should leave Washington unless they agree to pass a resolution backing the U.N. measure, which advocates force if necessary. Hamilton cautioned against Congress engaging in a long debate on the gulf if there is no widespread support one way or the other. ``It will send a signal of divisiveness. That's not what we want to do now,'' he said. On the deadlock over diplomatic discussions. Dole said Mohamed Al-Mashat, Iraq ambassador to the United States who is in Baghdad for consultations, told him in a Saturday night telephone call that Saddam may be willing to bend on the date. ``I had some indication there was some flexibility (by Iraq on the date),'' said Dole, adding ``there's got to be flexibility'' on Bush's part as well. Iraq has invited Secretary of State James Baker III to meet Saddam Hussein on Jan. 12, a date the White House has rejected because it is too close to the U.N. deadline. Bush's invitation to Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz to come to Washington last December fell through because of the deadlock over the Baker visit.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Albanian Jews Begin Immigrating To Israel
With AM-Albania
DOC.TEXT: Albanian Jews are being allowed to emigrate to Israel and several have already arrived, Israel army radio reported Sunday. Thirty-seven members of one family bound for Israel boarded a flight Sunday dubbed the ``Flying Carpet'' in Tirana, Albania's capital, and flew to Rome, said Shula Bahat, a spokeswoman for the American Jewish Committee in New York. ``This is going to save Albanian Jews from total extinction. Had they remained there, they would have been wiped out in a generation,'' said Rabbi Marc Tanenbaum, foreign relations consultant to the committee. One Tel Aviv man with relatives in Albania told the radio that the entire Jewish community of that country was packed and ready to leave for Israel. The Jews are not coming through official Israeli channels, but are sponsored by Jewish organizations and unofficial agencies, the radio said, quoting officials it did not identify. Yehdua Weinrab, spokesman for the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency, which is responsible for transporting immigrants to Israel, refused to comment on the exodus. Immigration Minister Yitzhak Peretz also refused to comment. The Tel Aviv man said some of his 60 relatives in Albania had immigrated in the past two months. The radio quoted unidentified officials who said Israeli Foreign Ministry delegates in Rome had arranged for the Italian embassy in Tirana to issue the travel permits. But Vladamir Prela, head of the Albanian Foreign Ministry's press department, denied there was a special program for the emigration of Jews from Albania. ``You may recall that Ramiz Alia (Communist party chief) has said those Albanian citizens who want to work abroad can leave. That also, obviously, applies to Jewish citizens,'' he said in a telephone interview. The exact number of Jews living in Albania was not available but estimated to be about 1,000 of the country's 3.2 million citizens. Albania's hard-line Communist government, which took power in 1944, until recently did not permit religious worship. Most of the Jews there are believed to no longer practice Judaism. The Albanian government is now carrying out political reform as well, including the legalization of some opposition.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Rocks Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake rocked Tokyo and its neighboring area Monday morning, the Central Meteorological Agency said. There were no immediate reports of damage or casualties from the 8:05 a.m. tremor, police said. The earthquake had a preliminary reading of 5.1 on the Richter scale, said the Meteorological Agency. It was centered in the eastern part of Chiba Prefecture, a state on the eastern border of Tokyo. The earthquake also registered 3 on the Japanese scale of 7 in Katsuura and Tateyama, two coastal cities in the state. It was strong enough to overturn unfastened objects. The Richter scale is a gauge of the strength of an earthquake as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. A quake measuring 5 on the scale can cause considerable damage. The Japanese scale measures the intensity of an earthquake at a particular location. It is not convertible to the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Project `Flying Carpet': Albania Allows Jews To Leave
With AM-Albania
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-seven members of an Albanian Jewish family on Sunday became the first Jews to be allowed to leave Albania under a deal secretly negotiated with the Communist government, an American Jewish group said. On a flight dubbed the ``Flying Carpet,'' the family left the Albanian capital of Tirana on Sunday, headed for Israel via Rome, said Shula Bahat, a spokeswoman for the American Jewish Committee. ``This is going to save Albanian Jews from total extinction,'' said the group's foreign relations consultant, Rabbi Marc Tanenbaum. ``Had they remained there, they would have been wiped out in a generation.'' In Rome, the family was aided by the Italian government and representatives of the Jerusalem-based Jewish Agency, Bahat said. Further details about the family were not immediately known. The Jewish Agency, which is financing the resettlement of Albanian Jews, negotiated in secret with the Albanian, Israeli and Italian governments to facilitate the immigration, she said. The family's departure forged the way to the West for Albania's 500 Jews, most of whom are expected to leave the repressive country after decades of being cut off from the world Jewish community, she said. Sunday's flight, as well as future flights to the West for Albania's Jews, has been nicknamed the ``Flying Carpet,'' Bahat said. She said Jews have not been allowed to practice their religion by Albania's government, one of the last in Eastern Europe to maintain a political hard line as surrounding countries turned to democracy. ``Jews were cut off and alienated in Albania, which was the leading Stalinist government in Eastern Europe,'' Tanenbaum said. ``Under that regime, religious and cultural freedom was totally denied. ``The only way the Albanian Jews could keep their tradition alive was by doing it underground and behind closed curtains,'' he said. ``This means they can finally breathe fresh air.'' The negotiations had not previously been made public because the issue was a delicate one, Bahat said. She did not know when the negotiations began. Other Albanian Jews who want to immigrate are expected to leave the country within the next three months, she said. In the past, some Jews have fled Albania via Greece.

DOC.HEAD: Precede RESTON, Va.
Earthquake Shakes South Pacific
DOC.NOTE: EDS: LEADS thruout to UPDATE with no injuries, minor damage; PRECEDES; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake hit Papua New Guinea's New Britain Island in the South Pacific early Monday, causing minor damage but no reported injuries. The earthquake was recorded at a preliminary magnitude of 6.8 on the Richter scale, according to U.S. Geological Survey scientists in Golden, Colo. New Britain is a narrow, crescent-shaped island with Rabaul on its northeast tip. The 375-mile-long island, home to about 200,000 people, has a rugged range of mountains with several active volcanoes. Ima Itikarai, who works at the government's volcanic activity scientific station in Rabaul, said minor damage was reported in scattered regions of the island. ``We have heard some reports of ground cracks, damage to water tanks and some roofs, and foundations displaced,'' said Itikarai. ``We have not had any reports of injuries.'' The epicenter of the tremor, which occurred at 5:14 a.m. Monday, was recorded about 110 miles southwest of Rabaul. Although an earthquake with a 6.8 magnitude on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage, Don Finley of the U.S. Geological Survey said quakes of such power occur frequently in the area and typically go unnoticed except by scientists. The Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven Arrested in Colorful White House Demonstration
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Inserts 3rd graf, ``Among those xxx to include Berrigan arrest
DOC.TEXT: Eleven people were arrested Sunday after they scaled the north fence of the White House and threw red ink, simulating blood, into a fountain, according to authorities. They were among a group of 40 demonstrators affiliated with the D.C. Coalition Against the U.S. in the Middle East, according to Doug Holmes of the uniformed division of the U.S. Secret Service. Among those arrested was former Catholic priest Philip Berrigan, a veteran anti-war activist. President Bush was at the presidential retreat at Camp David in the nearby Maryland mountains at the time of the arrests. Holmes said the eleven people were charged with destruction of government property and unlawful entry. Officials said one Secret Service officer suffered a minor injury during the incident. The 29 demonstrators who did not enter the White House grounds were not charged.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Immigration Official Calls For Tent Camps
DOC.TEXT: Immigration Minister Yitzhak Peretz presented his plan Sunday for housing tens of thousands of the coming year's expected 400,000 Soviet Jewish immigrants in tent camps and army bases. Peretz presented his plan to the ministerial committee on immigration. He he later fielded criticism of the tent camp proposal on Israel television, calling it ``an emergency plan for a time of distress.'' ``I am always afraid that there could be a situation where immigrants will get stuck at the airport, and we will have nowhere to put them,'' Peretz said on Israel television. The plan, which still must be approved by the Cabinet, calls for establishing tent camps to house 10,000 immigrants. Peretz defended his plan as one based on the successful absorption of about 200,000 immigrants in 1990. ``This is not just a theory or recommendation, but an orderly and organized plan that promises the proper absorption of 400,000 immigrants,'' Peretz said on Israel television. At the meeting, Israel's chief of staff, Dan Shomron, offered to house 70,000 newcomers in army camps and to clear four training fields for immigrant trailers. ``Such a mission as immigration, I would say, is the most important mission today, other than security,'' Shomron said on Israel army radio. ``We are talking about a solution for tens of thousands of immigrants; it is not simple at all for the army. It complicates things greatly, but it is an important mission, and we will do our part,'' Shomron added. Simha Dinitz, head of the quasi-governmental Jewish Agency responsible for transporting immigrants to Israel, has rejected tents as an outdated response to the housing shortage. He has cited mobile homes and trailers as preferable options. The government predicts one million Soviets will arrive by the end of 1992. Dinitz has said the figure could exceed two million before the wave of immigration ends. Housing is not the only problem the newcomers face. Israel television reported that the immigration minister's plan is based on the belief that by the end of 1991, 140,000 immigrants will be looking for work. Another 15,000 will be unemployed and 55,000 will be working at temporary jobs, the television said. Israel already has an unemployment rate that fluctuates between 8.8 and 10 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq: Bush `Must Have Been Drunk' To Think Saddam Would Back Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with Saddam comments on Iraqi TV; picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Vice President ...; Stands for AM-Gulf Rdp
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DHR1
DOC.TEXT: Iraq's information minister said Sunday that President Bush ``must have been drunk'' when he suggested Iraq might withdraw from Kuwait, and boasted: ``We will show the world America is a paper tiger.'' The minister, Latif Jassim, also insisted on Iraq's proposed date of Jan. 12 for a visit by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Washington has said that date is too close to the Jan. 15 U.N. deadline for Iraq to leave Kuwait or face possible force. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein delivered a 15-minute New Year's message Sunday on Iraqi TV in which he invoked both Moslem and Christian theology in condemning the United States and Saudi Arabia. CNN carried the broadcast and provided English subtitles. ``In this confrontation, there have been those who betrayed Jesus Christ and who betrayed the principles and values of Islam, one luring and leading the other,'' said Saddam. `May God curse them all.'' ``...As did Judas betray Jesus, so has Bush betrayed through his aggresion and deep-rooted evil, the teachings of Jesus Christ,'' he said. Vice President Dan Quayle told Saudi King Fahd on Sunday that the United States expects more money from the oil-rich nation for military efforts against Iraq, and the Arab ruler seemed to agree, U.S. officials said in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. No figures were mentioned, but U.S. officials left the two-hour meeting with the impression there will be no problem, they said. Saudi Arabia has cleared a windfall of billions from rising oil prices since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. Quayle also found ``no reticence'' on Fahd's part to the idea of launching a war against Iraq if Saddam does not withdraw from Kuwait, one senior U.S. official said. An official Baghdad newspaper said Sunday that Iraqis and other Arabs will attack U.S. and Western targets worldwide if America and its allies move militarily against Iraq. With the Jan. 15 deadline drawing near, foreign ministers of the 12-nation European Community were to meet Friday in Luxembourg to discuss the Persian Gulf crisis. The decision to hold an emergency meeting was announced Sunday by the French Foreign Ministry. The gathering had been proposed a day earlier by Germany's foreign minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, who appealed again Sunday for a fresh diplomatic effort to try to avoid war in the gulf. But Saddam insisted anew that any solution to the crisis must be linked to a resolution of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The United States, Israel and others have rejected any such linkage. The Iraqi News Agency said Saddam's renewed call for linkage came in talks Sunday with Yugoslavia's foreign minister. The Yugoslav official reportedly was seeking a new peace initiative on behalf of the non-aligned movement, of which Yugoslavia is the current chairman. The U.S. official with Quayle, who discussed his meeting with Fahd on condition of not being identified by name, said the two were ``in virtually complete agreement on what needed to be done'' to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Quayle's staff said there were no plans for him to launch any new diplomatic initiative during his three-day trip to Saudi Arabia. He was to visit U.S. troops and consult with the exiled emir of Kuwait. Jassim, at a Baghdad news conference, derided Bush's comment to Time magazine that he had a ``gut feeling'' Iraq might still withdraw from Kuwait. Iraq will never do so, Jassim said. Bush, he said, ``must have been drunk, and drunk people usually lose their senses.'' Jassim also repeated Iraq's insistence on the Jan. 12 date for talks between Baker and Saddam. ``Our president has set the date and that is the only possibility. There is no change,'' said Jassim. He said Iraq would not initiate hostilities in the gulf, telling reporters: ``We will never attack.'' ``But if Bush starts a war, he will not be able to stop it ... We will show the world that America is a paper tiger. You will see how the Americans will kneel down,'' he said. A Western diplomat, meanwhile, said U.S. charge d'affaires Joseph Wilson has stopped his almost daily efforts to talk to the Iraqis about the date for any direct talks. ``There are no forward movements, at least not in Baghdad,'' said the diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. The European decision to meet and discuss the crisis was welcomed by the Iraqi ambassador to the United States. But the envoy said Europe should adopt an independent approach to the gulf. ``It is high time for the Europeans to enunciate their own policy and not to be subservient to the American policy,'' Mohammad Sadek Mashat told reporters at Amman airport, where he stopped en route back to Washington after consultations in Baghdad. The Iraqi threat of terrorist attacks against U.S. and other installations came in the al-Thawra daily, which is the mouthpiece of Iraq's ruling Baath Socialist Party. ``Hundreds of thousands of volunteers are now at the highest state of readiness to fight against the alliance of evil and aggression,'' said the newspaper. The Iraqi News Agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted the newspaper as saying that if war breaks out in the gulf, ``the confrontation will not be confined to the battlefield.'' Iraq's religious affairs minister, Abdullah Fadil, warned Sunday that Moslems would retaliate against the United States and its allies if Islamic holy shrines were hit in any multinational offensive aimed at driving the Iraqis out of Kuwait. ``Every Moslem will be a missile to be thrown against the enemy once he launches his armed agression against Iraq,'' he told a news conference in Baghdad. U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia have been on heightened alert since before Christmas. A U.S. official said Sunday that the hotel housing the U.S. command's press center in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, was evacuated after a telephoned bomb threat. U.S. official said Saudi police searched the building but found nothing.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Gives Birth to Healthy Girl After Being Shot
DOC.TEXT: A pregnant woman was shot in the head and critically injured during a drive-by shooting Sunday, but doctors were able to deliver her child, police said. Marilyn Colon, 20, and Carlos Ventura, 26, were standing on a street near the Bronx Zoo early Sunday when a car pulled up and an occupant opened fire, said police Sgt. Grace Ridley. Ventura, who was hit five times, was killed, she said. Colon, who was eight months pregnant, was shot in the head. Doctors at Bronx Municipal Hospital Center operated immediately and delivered a 5-pound, 11-ounce girl, said Vicki Ciampa, a hospital spokeswoman. ``The baby is doing good,'' Ciampa said. Police said they knew of no motive for the shooting and said no arrests had been made.

DOC.HEAD: Levy Warns United States Of Hostile Forces In Jordan
DOC.TEXT: Foreign Minister David Levy told a U.S. lawmaker Sunday that pro-Iraqi forces in Jordan are using it as a base for anti-American and anti-Israeli activity. Jordan is becoming a threat because of ``hostile fundamentalist factors which are gaining in strength constantly,'' Levy was quoted as saying by a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry. The spokesman, who could not be identified under briefing regulations, quoted Levy as telling visiting Rep. James Scheuer, D-New York, that King Hussein of Jordan is concentrating security forces on Israel's border. Jordanian military sources said Thursday they had increased their forces along the border as a precaution against an attack by the Jewish state. Israeli officials earlier sought to assure Hussein that they had no plans to attack. They said Jordanian officials were really worried about pro-Iraqi forces crossing the border into Israel and creating a pretext for an Israeli strike. Israel's chief of staff, Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron, said last week that Iraq could use Jordan as a springboard for action against Israel. In Sunday's meeting, Levy told Scheuer that Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had a ``stockpile of missiles which could indeed reach Israel within a few minutes, and out of consideration for the U.S. and its soldiers, we take a risk and adopt a low profile.'' ``It should be noted that Israel will not always maintain only a low profile,'' Levy said. Iraq has threatened to attack Israel with chemical warheads if war breaks out in the gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Air Raid on Southern Lebanon Hits Target Near Sidon
DOC.TEXT: Israeli warplanes bombed guerrilla targets in south Lebanon on Sunday to wipe out a base used for attacks against Israel, army officials said. The army command said the Israeli warplanes ``attacked and hit a guerrilla target southeast of Sidon'' and Israeli planes returned safely. The command did not say which guerrilla organization had been attacked. There was no report on casualties or any other details. Israel has launched 19 such air raids this year.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev to Promote Pan-Asian Summit on Easing Military Tensions
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev said in an interview published Sunday he seeks a Pan-Asian summit, including the United States, to discuss ways to ease military confrontations in the region. Gorbachev also told the Asahi Shimbun newspaper that he hoped Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze would continue to work with him, despite his Dec. 20 announcement he was resigning. ``I consider him one of my closest comrades, and there were no differences in opinions or views,'' Gorbachev said. The Supreme Soviet is to consider Shevardnadze's resignation on Jan. 8. Meanwhile, Gorbachev said, ``I told him to continue his work.'' The aim of an Asian summit would be to demilitarize the region and create a ``stabilized, neighborly and cooperative zone,'' Gorbachev said in the interview in Moscow on Friday with the nationally circulated Japanese newspaper. ``Such a meeting could not be considered without the participation of the United States, Canada, Australia and New Zealand,'' Gorbachev said. On unification of the divided Korean peninsula, Gorbachev said that only North and South Koreans have the right to decide steps that can lead to that. But ``the Soviet Union is ready to participate in any international framework of cooperation and guarantee if necessary,'' he said. Gorbachev urged the Japanese government to end its policy of linking all issues between the two countries to its demand for return of the Soviet-held islands just off Japan's northern coast. He said the time has come for both nations to advance toward conclusion of a peace treaty to World War II. Gorbachev is to become the first Soviet leader to visit Japan in April. Asahi said that when asked about the Pan-Asian summit proposed by Shevardnadze in September, Gorbachev said the date and site would be discussed at Asian foreign ministerial talks scheduled in 1993 at Vladivostok, home port of the Soviet navy's Pacific fleet.

DOC.HEAD: `Dude Ranch' Operator Hosted Celebrity Divorce-Seekers
DOC.TEXT: Harry Drackert, whose ``dude ranches'' were briefly home to playwright Arthur Miller, Mary Rockefeller and other luminaries establishing Nevada residency in order to get divorces, has died at age 87. He died Wednesday at a Reno hospital of heart failure. Drackert was among the last survivors of the dozen or so guest-ranch operators who hosted out-of-state residents drawn to Nevada by the state's liberal divorce laws. The laws, for many years the most liberal in the nation, allowed a person to get a Nevada divorce after just a six-week residency in the state. From the 1940s to the 1960s, Drackert and his wife, Joan, operated three guest ranches, including the Donner Trail guest ranch in Verdi and the Silver Circle Ranch in Reno. In February 1962, the Donner Trail ranch gained national attention when Mary Rockefeller, wife of then New York Gov. Nelson Rockefeller, moved in for six weeks. Upon her arrival, she announced she was seeking a divorce from the prominent Republican presidential candidate. Other guests included Miller, author Saul Bellow and Evelyn Funt, the ex-wife of Candid Camera creator Allen Funt. Drackert, a native of Bozeman, Mont., won many saddle bronco competitions as a rodeo rider in the 1920s and 1930s, and won a steer decorating championship in 1931 at the Calgary Stampede. He also bred and trained horses. He is survived by his wife, Joan, a noted trapshooter.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding in Midwest, New Storm in Northwest
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to move up graf on death toll, which has risen to 99. Picks up 3rd graf pvs, `Temperatures dipped ...' DELETES now redundant 11th graf, `Since the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Flooding forced evacuations and closed roads Sunday in Indiana and Ohio, and a new storm headed into wind-ravaged Washington state with a threat of snow and high wind. Highways were icy across parts of the Plains and towing services were kept busy with cars that wouldn't start or stay on the road. ``We're getting three to four times the normal number of calls,'' said Mark Moody at Oklahoma City's AAA. Since the start of the season's first strong cold wave on Dec. 18, at least 99 deaths, including 20 in Texas, have been attributed to the weather. Temperatures dipped to numbing lows again Sunday, including a record 23 below zero at Scottsbluff, Neb., 30 below at Rapid City, S.D., a record for the whole month of December, and an unofficial 40 below at Porcupine, S.D. Even Honolulu joined in with an untropical record low of 57. Some church services were canceled around Mitchell, S.D., which hit 24 below, said J.P. Skelly of station KORN in Mitchell. Temperatures have dropped below freezing nightly for close to two weeks in many areas of California. Sacramento has had a record 11 consecutive nights with freezing temperatures. ``It's all people are talking about. It's affecting everyone. People are losing their jobs over it,'' said Lori Segrue, who works at a vineyard in Kingsburg, south of Fresno. California Gov. George Deukmejian declared a state of emergency in the Santa Cruz Mountains where public water systems were shut down by the cold. Officials said water service had been restored to all but about 10 percent of the San Fernando Valley's 5,000 customers by Sunday morning. Broken pipes, which caused most of the trouble by draining storage tanks, will have to be repaired before service is fully restored. Some agriculture experts estimate that the cost of the state's crop damage caused by freezing weather could total $1 billion. Two North Dakota farmers, Clarence Campbell, 79, and his brother William, 77, were found dead near their farmhouse at Eckelson Saturday after apparently attempting to walk across a field to a relative's house and being overcome by the bitter cold, authorities said. Temperatures dropped to a record 37 below in the area at the weekend. Two days of heavy rain combined with melting snow to push streams out of their banks in many areas around Indiana. Scattered evacuations were reported in several communities, including Indianapolis. Countless roads were closed by high water, officials said. Indiana Emergency Management Director Jerry Hauer said he was concerned that rivers were still rising and had not crested yet. Additional rain, sleet and snow fell Sunday. ``I'd say we've got a pretty serious situation on our hands,'' Hauer said. The flooding will grow worse later in the week, said Al Shipe, a National Weather Service hydrologist in Indianapolis. The Mississinewa River was forecast to crest 5 feet above flood stage for its worst flooding at Marion since 1958, and Indianapolis was due to receive the highest levels along the White River since 1964, Shipe said. ``It's very grim right now,'' said sheriff's Deputy Ken Lopez in Delaware County, Ind. Dozens of residents were evacuated in two northern Ohio towns because of high water. Delphos police and fire departments ordered at least 80 people to leave two trailer courts. Near Cleveland, 30 to 50 people were evacuated along the Chagrin River, said Willoughby Hills Fire Department Lt. Sandra Thorne. In the Northwest, battered by high wind Friday that damaged coastal property and knocked down trees and power lines, the weather service issued another winter storm warning for the Puget Sound area and upgraded a storm watch to a storm warning for north-central and northeastern Washington. Repair crews worked over the weekend to shore up sea walls that were undercut by Friday's storm. The storm also knocked out power to about 150,000 utility customers from Puget Sound to the British Columbia border. By Sunday morning, Puget Power Sound and Light Co. still had about 16,800 customers without electricity, said spokeswoman Jude Noland. Parts of Arkansas got combinations of heavy sleet, light snow and some thunderstorms Sunday morning. Benton County had the heaviest accumulation with 4 to 6 inches of snow and ice and roads there and elsewhere were slippery. Ice buildup knocked tree limbs into power lines and caused hundreds of new power outages, said Jerol Garrison, a spokesman for Arkansas Power and Light. He did not yet have exact numbers.
